channel.title: CryptyCC
channel.description: An Attempt To Explain Cryptography The Easy Way

item.title: Hello world!
item.dc:creator: prithuadhikary
item.content:encoded: Welcome to WordPress. This is your first post. Edit or delete it, then start writing!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi, this is a comment. To get started with moderating, editing, and deleting comments, please visit the Comments screen in the dashboard. Commenter avatars come from Gravatar.

item.title: Sample Page
item.dc:creator: prithuadhikary
item.content:encoded:
This is an example page. It's different from a blog post because it will stay in one place and will show up in your site navigation (in most themes). Most people start with an About page that introduces them to potential site visitors. It might say something like this:
Hi there! I'm a bike messenger by day, aspiring actor by night, and this is my website. I live in Los Angeles, have a great dog named Jack, and I like piña coladas. (And gettin' caught in the rain.)
...or something like this:
The XYZ Doohickey Company was founded in 1971, and has been providing quality doohickeys to the public ever since. Located in Gotham City, XYZ employs over 2,000 people and does all kinds of awesome things for the Gotham community.
As a new WordPress user, you should go to your dashboard to delete this page and create new pages for your content. Have fun!

item.title: ECDH - The Key Agreement Scheme
item.dc:creator: prithuadhikary
item.content:encoded:
We humans have tried endlessly over centuries to hide secrets. In doing so, we came up with various mechanisms to convey our messages with secrecy or privacy. And thus, yes, we have devised various encryption techniques that we can employ to hide our data at rest and at motion. Just to draw an analogy, these encryption techniques or schemes so to speak, act as small opaque boxes, that can be opened only with a key, the sender has to place the message inside this box, use the key that works to lock it up, and then send it over to the receiver, who has a similar key to open it up and read the message. When the keys look alike(are exactly similar), it is called a symmetric encryption scheme, and in some cases, where the keys to lock the box and open the box are different, it is called a public key encryption scheme. Though, in the digital world, this is modeled using the magic of mathematics. The security of data at rest is quite trivial to implement, because, often, the sender and the receiver are the same entity which has the key to encrypt and decrypt the data, but when it comes to the data in motion, it simply is not that trivial. When data is in transit, it is usually flowing through a public network and anyone with some know-how can sniff the traffic and see what's flowing through the wire. And hence, it is inevitable to encrypt the data that is flowing. But, in the world of internet, how would we ensure that two parties(often a server and a browser) who have never seen each other before, talk to each other over an encrypted channel? Primary problem in this case being, a secret key, which both ought to have which they can't send over through the network, so that one can encrypt and the other can decrypt. So, there has to be a mechanism to share a secret key. And, thus comes into the picture, Elliptic Curve Diffie Hellman or ECDH in short. It is an algorithm that comes under the class of Diffie Hellman key exchange algorithms but uses elliptic curve cryptography under the hood. Let us just quickly recap what the basic Diffie-Hellman key exchange with multiplicative group of integers looked like for two people Alice and Bob:

Diffie-Hellman Key Exchange Over Multiplicative Group Of Integers:

  1. Alice and Bob choose a modulus p and a base g. For our basic example, let us take: p = 27 and g = 5. Why 5?, because it is a primitive root or a generator of multiplicative group of integers modulo 27, i.e. if you keep on multiplying 5 with itself and mod each result with 27, you will generate all the possible values in the set { 1, 2, 3, .... ,26 }. Or in other words: The set Φ = { 5^n mod 27 } such that, ∀ n ∈ { 1, 2, ...,p-1 } you will generate a set containing all the values that we get by mod'ing a number n by p = 27.
  2. Alice chooses a secret integer a = 7 and raises the generator g to a and mod's it by p = 27. Let it be A = (g ^ a) mod p => A = (5 ^ 7) mod 27 = 78125 mod 27 => A = 14. This A is Alice's public key and is sent over to Bob.
  3. Bob chooses a secret integer b = 3 and raises g to b and mod's it by p. So, public key for Bob becomes, B = (g ^ b) mod p => B = (5 ^ 3) mod 27 => B = 125 mod 27 => B = 17 and this is sent over to Alice.
  4. Alice computes the shared key as: S = (B ^ a) mod p => S = (17 ^ 7) mod 27 = 17
  5. Bob computes the shared key as: S = (A ^ b) mod p => S = (14 ^ 3) mod 27 = 17
This works because the multiplicative group of integers exhibits all the properties of a cyclic group including the commutative property, i.e.: ((g ^ a) ^ b) mod p = (g ^ ab) mod p = (g ^ ba) mod p = ((g ^ b) ^ a) mod p Hence, we see, both Alice and Bob have the shared secret key 17. And as always, Eve the eavesdropper will have to work out the discrete logarithm problem to figure out what private key Alice and Bob have. This difficulty is further exponentiated when the field chosen is Z/Zp with p beyond the order of 2^192. But how does this pan out in the case of elliptic curves? Elliptic curves are of the form: Let us use sage to plot one. It is a nice mathematical tool using which we can plot equations and do a lot of stuff like plotting them in different fields such as rational fields or finite integer fields, carry out point additions etc. For plotting an elliptic curve with the above equation over Rational Field R, we can do the following: sage: C = EllipticCurve([0, 1, 0, 0, 1])    # constructor takes values of coefficients in the                                                                              # generic elliptic curve equation, refer sage website Elliptic Curve defined by y^2 = x^3 + x^2 + 1 over Rational Field sage: P = plot(C) sage: P.show() And soon an image will pop up: Ya, that is how it looks like. To understand ECC, let us only concentrate on the geometric interpretations of the fundamental principals that it is based on. Because, the next thing we will do is use the OpenSSL's C Library to model a dummy ECDH key exchange without delving too much into the mathematics. :) While recaping the simple DH key exchange scheme, we observed that the scheme works because the field over which the computations are done is a finite integer field often denoted by a symbol Z/Zp, Zp here is the finite set of integers { 0, 1, 2 ... , p-1 } such that p is a prime. And the co-domain is essentially a cyclic group where all the elements of the cyclic group can be generated by a group generator element operated over by a group operation repetitively. So, a group is actually a set of elements and a group operation. In case of Diffie-Hellman over multiplicative group of integers, the group operation was exponentiation of the generator g. But as it turns out in case of elliptic curves, we will define something else because it just does the job :). Let us define an addition operation denoted by '+' such that the addition of any two points P, Q is the reflection of the point where a line joining P and Q intersects the curve: Sounding complicated? Well it is not that complicated, at least geometrically. Let us have a look. In the above image, you can see that the line joining the points P and Q is intersecting the curve at -R, and the reflection of -R, i.e. R is the result of the addition operation. Now imagine, Q tending to P. As Q tends to P, the line tends to become a tangent to the curve at point P, and thus we get P+P or 2P as the reflection of point -R where the tangent passing through P intersects the curve. Till now, we were operating on the rational field R. Now let us examine, how the elliptic curve looks like in a finite field Z/Zp. Sage also helps us out here to visualize how it would look. Let's plot the same curve over Z/Z23: sage: Zp = FiniteField(23) sage: C = EllipticCurve(Zp, [0, 1, 0, 0, 1]) sage: C Elliptic Curve defined by y^2 = x^3 + x^2 + 1 over Finite Field of size 23 sage: Cp = plot(C) It is evident from the above plot, that the symmetry that we observed while plotting the curve over rational field, exists even when we plot it over the finite field. And same as before, let's visualize what a point addition might look like in this case: In the above diagram we can observe that: Point P is (1, 16), Q is (8, 18) and geometrically performing addition of those using a scale and a pencil, we can arrive at a result R = (22, 1). One thing to note here is, the elliptic curve equation looks a little bit different when defined over Z/Zp: Let us just quickly validate this addition using sage: And indeed, we can see that the point addition yields the point (22,1). The nice thing about the field Z/Z23 is, the moment, the value of the co-ordinates (x, y) of the resultant point exceed 23, it wraps around, following modular arithmetic. Thus the resultant x's and y's stay within the field Z/Z23. Now let us examine an important property of this addition operation using sage. Let us check if this operation is a commutative one. Because, if it is commutative and the group is cyclic, we can use it in Diffie-Hellman key exchange? Right? Like we did with the multiplicative group of integers? And let us do this validation with multiples of the Generator point G. Cool! Isn't it. It definitely is a commutative one. Note here, that multiplying a point P with 2 means P + P, which also stands for higher multiples. So, 2*G is G+G and 10*G is... well you guessed it right. :) Also, let us check if this point R is on the curve or not? We did a couple of things here, first, we printed out the curve associated with point R, and it indeed is the one that we have been operating with, since the beginning. Secondly, we extracted out the (x,y) co-ordinates of the point R, which turned out to be (18, 19) and then extracted out another point ValidPoint on curve C using those co-ordinates, and we did not see an error. It usually throws an error if the point is not on the curve. So, we can safely say, point R is definitely on the curve defined by the variable C, and R belongs to the set of all the 30 points on C(invoke C.cardinality() to see for yourself) which is defined over the finite field Z/Z23. So, P and Q were on the curve C, the result of addition R is also on the curve C. P, Q and R, all belong to the set of 30 points that the curve C has in total. That means the resultant points are the ones in the group itself. So, the group is cyclic too! Yes we are not validating all the points on the curve here. But the motive here is to identify a tool using which we can test that indeed, the points on the elliptic curve defined over a finite integer field is a cyclic group. Hence, it can be used for conducting a Diffie-Hellman key exchange. Now, since we have established that we can do DH with Elliptic Curves, let us jump right onto ECDH. :)

Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman

Let us assume that we have the usual crowd, Alice and Bob, who want to secretly communicate and Eve who is the eavesdropper and sniffing the traffic between Alice and Bob. So, the key agreement is done as follows:
  1. Alice and Bob agree on a set of elliptic curve parameters. Most of the times a sage elliptic curve name(see https://safecurves.cr.yp.to/) is enough to identify the domain parameters which is a sextuple: (p, a, b, G, n, h) We can quickly identify the significance of a few of them by looking at the equation itself: a is coefficient of x, b is a constant, p is the finite field size. What about G? Yes, it is the generator point and n is the order of G(or the number of points G can generate including the identity element). In some cases(which we have not examined yet), a generator point might not be able to generate all the points on the curve, but fewer. In that case, there is a property called co-factor h of a generator G, and it is defined as (order of C)/(order of G). The h in the sextuple is that co-factor and n is the order of G.
  2. Alice chooses a constant α between 1 and p-1 and multiples it with the generator G to find another point A on the curve. In short, he does, A = αG Alice then sends over A to Bob and keeps α to himself. Hence, A is the public key, and α is the private key.
  3. Bob does the same: B = βG Sends B to Alice as public key and keeps β to himself as private key.
  4. Eve intercepts the traffic and scratches his head.
  5. Alice receives B from Bob and computes S(a shared key) as: S = (Alice's private key) * (Bob's public key which is a point) => S = αB But B was βG, so S ends up as: S = αβG
  6. Bob computes something similar: S = (Bob's private key) * (Alice's public key which is a point) => S = βA But A was αG, so S ends up as: S = βαG => S = αβGSo, we can see that both Alice and Bob arrive at the same point S on the curve. Let us model this interaction on sage and see if Alice and Bob can indeed arrive at the same point? Next: We will look into some example C code performing ECDH using OpenSSL's EVP library.

item.title: ECDH Example - OpenSSL EVP Library
item.dc:creator: prithuadhikary
item.content:encoded:
In this post, we will look into how ECDH can be carried out using the OpenSSLs C Library, namely the EVP library. The code fragments that we will refer to, is from a github repository located at: GitHub: ECDH Example Using OpenSSL Library For two parties to carry out the ECDH key agreement, we have do a few things:
  1. Agree On Elliptic Curve Domain Parameters: Both parties need to agree on the elliptic curve domain parameters that they intend to use for carrying out ECDH. We will use a predefined named curve that has been published in X9.62 standard and is named "Curve prime256v1".
  2. Generate a key-pair: Both the parties attempting to perform ECDH need to generate a key pair or a pair of public and private keys. The public key is intended to be transmitted over to the other party un-encrypted.
  3. Exchange public keys: Both parties then need to exchange the public keys. For our case, we will just extract the public key from the private key and pretend, Alice got Bob's and vice versa. :D Also for our convenience, we will print out the private key, which will be a huge number, and also the x and y co-ordinates of the public key, which themselves be huge numbers.
  4. Compute the shared key: Then we will invoke EVP library methods to compute the shared key and will also validate if they are same or not. In practice, the shared key thus generated is generally further hashed using a hash function to be used with an appropriate symmetric encryption scheme such as AES, DES etc.
Now let us dive into some code, shouldn't we? :) Generating Key Pair: In the method: 
EVP_PKEY* generateKey();
The first thing that you will notice is, we declare some EVP PKEY_CTX(evp public key context) and EVP_PKEY(evp public key) type pointers: 
EVP_PKEY_CTX *paramGenCtx = NULL, *keyGenCtx = NULL;
EVP_PKEY *params= NULL, *keyPair= NULL;
As you will see, these variables will be initialized later. The key generation is a two step process, first we need to generate a EVP_PKEY structure instance containing the parameters that need to be used for ECDH, here pointed by the pointer params. Then using the structure containing the parameters, the key pair is generated, and for that, a separate EVP_PKEY_CTX structure is used. The key pair hence generated will be pointed by the pointer keyPair. Note that, these structures are provided by the EVP library itself. Let us see how params is initialized: 
paramGenCtx = EVP_PKEY_CTX_new_id(EVP_PKEY_EC, NULL);

if(!EVP_PKEY_paramgen_init(paramGenCtx)) handleErrors();

EVP_PKEY_CTX_set_ec_paramgen_curve_nid(paramGenCtx, NID_X9_62_prime256v1);

EVP_PKEY_paramgen(paramGenCtx, &params);
First thing is to create a new instance of EVP_PKEY_CTX for elliptic curve parameter generation and initialize it by calling EVP_PKEY_paramgen_init(paramGenCtx) Next, we need to configure the paramGenCtx to generate parameters for a named curve. In this case, the prime256v1 curve from X9.62 standard. We do this by calling 
EVP_PKEY_CTX_set_ec_paramgen_curve_nid(paramGenCtx, NID_X9_62_prime256v1);
The above call configures the paramGenCtx for generation of the ECDH parameters. Now we can invoke the method to generate the parameters using the paramGenCtx as follows: 
EVP_PKEY_paramgen(paramGenCtx, &params);
The above method takes in a pointer to a pointer to create a structure and store it at the address of params or &params. After this call, the params pointer points to a EVP_PKEY structure instance containing the parameters that can be used to generate a key pair. The next few lines are similar to the previous ones: 
keyGenCtx = EVP_PKEY_CTX_new(params, NULL);
if(!EVP_PKEY_keygen_init(keyGenCtx)) handleErrors();
if(!EVP_PKEY_keygen(keyGenCtx, &keyPair)) handleErrors();
Here also, we create a new EVP_PKEY_CTX and store it's address in keyGenCtx pointer, but instead of creating it with an id for generating parameters, we are directly passing the parameter structure's address to it for using it for generating the key pair. The following calls initialize the keyGenCtx and uses it to generate the key pair and store it's reference in the pointer keyPair. And that is it! The keyPair now points to a usable elliptic curve key pair! You will see some additional code in the generateKey method, but that just prints the public and the private components of the key pair generated. Next, let us briefly discuss the method: 
derivedKey* deriveShared(EVP_PKEY *publicKey, EVP_PKEY *privateKey)
The method signature describes a lot about the functionality implemented. This takes in a public key and a private key and derives a derived key. Though the derivedKey pointer here is a custom structure that we defined above the main method, and has two members, the char* secret and an int length. 
 derivedKey *dk = (derivedKey *)malloc(sizeof(derivedKey));

 EVP_PKEY_CTX *derivationCtx = NULL;

 derivationCtx = EVP_PKEY_CTX_new(privateKey, NULL);

 EVP_PKEY_derive_init(derivationCtx);
The first four lines of code are pretty straightforward. We create a EVP_PKEY_CTX again but pass the privateKey pointer to the creating method. This creates a pkey context for derivation. Then we initialize the context for derivation of the shared secret by invoking the derive_init method. The next few lines are: 
EVP_PKEY_derive_set_peer(derivationCtx, publicKey);
if(1 != EVP_PKEY_derive(derivationCtx, NULL, &dk->length)) handleDerivationErrors(0);

if(NULL == (dk->secret = OPENSSL_malloc(dk->length))) handleDerivationErrors(1);

if(1 != (EVP_PKEY_derive(derivationCtx, dk->secret, &dk->length))) handleDerivationErrors(2);
The first line has the call to set the public key in the derivation context. On the second line, we are passing the address of the dk->length variable so that the method can set the length(in bytes) of the derivable secret. On the third line, we dynamically allocate a character array of length dk->length and store it's address in dk->secret so that we can give it to a library method, which in turn can derive the secret and store it in the array pointed by dk->secret pointer. And on the last line, we call the derive method, which populates the dk->secret. The following is a run of the C program. It is quite simple to understand:
  1. Alice generates a key pair.
  2. Bob generates a key pair.
  3. Alice computes the shared secret using his private key and Bob's public key.
  4. Bob computes the shared secret using his private key and Alice's public key.
  5. At the end we can see, secrets generated by Alice and Bob are same.
And that is the magic of ECDH. Hope you enjoyed the blogs on ECDH. Please do leave comments/suggestions if you find something improper or incorrect. And do let me know your feedback at : prithu.adhikary@gmail.com <- Previous: ECDH – The Key Agreement Scheme

item.content:encoded:
This site is a small effort to explain basic crypto concepts and modern cryptography. Table Of Contents:
  • ECDH – The Key Agreement Scheme
  • ECDH Example – OpenSSL EVP Library

item.dc:creator: prithuadhikary
item.content:encoded:
CRYPTOgraphy concepts

The Four Pillars Of Cryptography - Cryptographic Services

Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman

ECDH - The Key Agreement Scheme

ECDH Example Using OpenSSL EVP Library

item.title: simplent
item.dc:creator: prithuadhikary

item.title: The Four Pillars Of Cryptography - Cryptographic Services
item.dc:creator: prithuadhikary
item.content:encoded:
Without further ado, let us just list those four pillars:
  1. Privacy
  2. Authenticity
  3. Integrity
  4. Non-Repudiation
Let us try to understand what these pillars are all about:
  1. Privacy : Imagine you and your friend need to have a private talk, so that no one else can hear it. What would you do? You two would usually go inside a soundproof room and have your conversation, right? But often, this kind of a scenario is not possible over the internet, to put it in the simplest form, if you communicate over the wire, anyone who has tapped into the wire, will be able to listen to your conversation. But, what if, you and your peer, figured out a scheme using which you can convert the message to a non-understandable form, send it over the wire and then convert it back to an understandable form? By doing so, you both will be able to communicate, and even if someone taps into the wire, he/she will hear gibberish, right?And hence comes into the picture, encryption. The most fundamental scheme that ensures the first pillar privacy. Privacy is also considered a cryptographic service, because cryptography is providing the service of securing the messages. Over the centuries, various such schemes were devised by humans, starting with the simplest centuries ago, to the highly advanced schemes of the current times. These schemes, as obvious, are modeled using mathematical functions called encryption functions that take in some plain-text either bit by bit or a block of bits at a time, and spit out cipher-text and inverse functions called decryption functions that take cipher-text in and spit out plain-text. So, to  summarize in a simple diagram:
  2. Authenticity: Again, as the name suggests, it is a service that ensures the source of a message. Imagine you have two friends A and B. B sends you a message pretending to be A. How would you know if the message is authentic and indeed sent by A? This problem is solved using a process called signing. In the real world, if you were to ascertain that the message was indeed sent by A, firstly you would have mandated that every sender needs to sign beneath the message, and then, on receiving any message, you would have matched A's signature. Matching every nuance of the signature, you could have safely concluded whether the message was authentic or not (just leave out the possibility of forgery here :P). In the crypto world though, it is not that simple, the image of a signature can be copied and pasted numerous times keeping all the nuances intact. So, how do we solve this problem?Comes to the rescue, digital signatures. Reading the name you might have landed on to the same conclusion of an image, but just scrap it. It is not what it sounds like. I know it is too soon and we have not discussed about public key cryptography. But for the time being, just know that, each one of you and our friends will have a public key and a private key(the duo is called a key-pair). Public key, as the name suggests, is public and available to all. So, you will have A's public key, B's public key etc. And they also will have a copy of your public key. The private key  on the other hand is private and only the owner of a specific key-pair knows about it. So, you know your private key, A knows his and B knows his. Now, digital signatures work in two steps:
    1. Signature Generation: A mathematical function takes in the original message and the sender's private key and spits out a long string of a pre defined length, called the digital signature. This digital signature is also sent with the message to the receiver.
    2. Signature Verification: A mathematical function takes in the digital signature and the public key of the sender,and spits out true or false. True for a match and false for a mismatch.
    Now let us see how this will work in the aforementioned scenario, when B sends you a message, he will have to generate a signature to attach to the message. But, B doesn't have the private key of A, so he might sign it with some random key and send it to you. While validating the signature, you will test it against A's public key, and the validation will fail, because the signature was no generated using A's private key. Since a picture is worth a thousand words:
  3. Integrity: Integrity and authenticity go hand in hand. As the name suggests, this service ensures that the message has not been tampered with. This also is achieved by using a mathematical function which takes in the original message and digests or hashes it to produce a digest(essentially a string of some sort). The difference between an encryption function and a digest is, a digest can not be reversed to the original message. It is a one way operation. The digest is also sent with the original message. The utility of digest is, if the message was tampered even by a bit,the digest will differ. So the receiver, after receiving the message can calculate the digest and match it to the digest that came with the message, if the digest differ, the receiver can conclude that the message was tampered it. There is another concept, called Keyed-Hashing or Keyed-Digest, which means, the digest function will not only take in the original message but also a key of a defined length to generate the digest. Such kind of an operation can achieve both, authenticity and integrity, and the digest thus generated is called a Message Authentication Code or MAC in short.  We will look into one such scheme called the HMAC or Hashed Message Authentication Code in forthcoming blog entries.
  4. Non-Repudiation: This service is actually a consequence of the second service that we discussed, that is authenticity. Just for your information, "repudiation" as per the dictionary, means, "denial of the truth or validity of something". Let us recap the scenario described while discussing authenticity, you have two friends A and B. Everyone knows each other's public key and everyone knows their own private key. Now consider a case where B sent you a message with his own signature which you were able to validate with B's public key. Now, B says, he has not sent you that message. But is it possible? The answer is no, if B's signature is a valid one, then definitely B sent you the message. So, B can not refute or repudiate the fact that he has sent the message. And that is non-repudiation, the sender can not refuse the ownership of a sent message signed by him/her.Adios my friends, we will meet later with another such blog entry where we will take each of the services one by one, and delve deeper into them, discussing symmetric and public key cryptography, hashing, message authentication codes, key exchange protocols and ending this series with a primer on public key infrastructure.
